questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He has received all age-appropriate screenings and immunizations. His 7-year-old brother was treated for nephrotic syndrome 1 year ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows 1+ protein. A subsequent urinalysis of an early morning sample shows:


Blood
negative


Glucose
negative


Protein
trace


Leukocyte esterase
negative


Nitrite
negative


RBC
none


WBC
0–1/hpf


Protein/creatinine ratio

0.2 (N ≤ 0.2)



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat urine dipstick in one year
Measure serum creatinine and urea nitrogen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This afebrile child initially presented with ≥ 1+ proteinuria, after which repeat testing of the first-morning urine and urinalysis with microscopic examination were indicated. The follow-up test showed normal urinalysis findings and a normal urinary protein/creatinine ratio (UPCR) ≤ 0.2, making transient proteinuria the most likely diagnosis. This type of benign proteinuria has an excellent prognosis; usually, no treatment is necessary. Therefore, a repeat urine dipstick of first-morning urine in one year is the most appropriate next step in management.

If follow-up examination had shown a UPCR > 0.2 or abnormal urinalysis findings (e.g., pyuria, hematuria), more extensive evaluation to exclude kidney disease, including laboratory studies (creatinine, BUN, electrolytes, albumin, cholesterol) and renal ultrasound, would have been necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney biopsy is not a routine part of the work-up for proteinuria. It would, however, be considered in nephrotic syndrome that is refractory to steroids, persistent hematuria, or sustained hypertension, or to rule out vasculitides (e.g., clinically ambiguous case of Henoch-Schönlein purpura). This patient is otherwise well and has no evidence of advanced renal disease, meaning that kidney biopsy is not appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is the preferred method of assessing for anatomical abnormalities of the kidneys and urinary tract. It can quickly identify hydronephrosis, megaureter, polycystic kidneys, and other structural pathologies. This imaging study is indicated in the work-up of proteinuria with chronic kidney disease. The patient described here has no history of kidney disease, making ultrasound inappropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipid profiles are used in the differential diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome because several etiologies manifest with hyperlipidemia. Although this patient has laboratory evidence of proteinuria, it is not close to nephrotic range proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day, which is equivalent to ∼ 3+ or 4+ on a dipstick reading, or a protein:creatinine ratio ≥ 3:1 on spot urine) and there are no other signs of nephrotic syndrome (e.g., edema). In addition, although a lipid profile is indicated in patients aged between 9 and 11 years, this patient has already received all age-appropriate screenings. Therefore, a lipid profile is unlikely to provide useful information at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

24-hour urine protein collection could be helpful in gathering more information about this patient's proteinuria. Current guidelines, however, recommend a single-void urine protein/creatinine ratio in children because it is easier to acquire and correlates with the 24-hour urine protein study (creatinine is secreted at a relatively constant rate of 1 g/24 hours). 24-hour urine protein collection is indicated if patients present with proteinuria that is > 4 mg/m2/h.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine and BUN values provide insight into renal function and can be used to help identify acute kidney injury (AKI) or monitor renal activity if an AKI has already been diagnosed. Additionally, the BUN:creatinine ratio can also provide clues as to the cause of AKI (either prerenal, intrinsic, or postrenal). However, this patient shows no signs of AKI (e.g, oliguria, hematuria); measuring serum creatinine and BUN would be unnecessary at this time.

G) INCORRECT:

Anti-nuclear antibody titers are an essential aspect of diagnosing autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus. Lupus can cause mild proteinuria, which is seen in this child. Typically, however, there is evidence of hematuria and multisystem involvement, e.g., malar rash, recurrent fever, and/or arthritis. This patient is otherwise well, with no other signs or symptoms aside from isolated proteinuria, making an autoimmune condition unlikely.
questions.hint: Transient proteinuria is the most common cause of positive protein on a urine dipstick test.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. Two days ago, he had a routine health maintenance examination that showed 3+ proteinuria on urine dipstick testing. During the initial routine examination, the patient reported feeling well, apart from being exhausted after an 8-hour shift at work. He had an upper respiratory infection 1 month ago, which resolved spontaneously within 5 days of onset. He has no history of serious illness. He works as an intern at a shooting range, where he does not usually use appropriate hearing protection. Today, he appears tired and complains about the early morning doctor's appointment before his morning shift. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 81.5 kg (180 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. There is mild sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Urea
8 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Urine



Glucose
negative


Protein
1+


Blood
negative


Nitrite
negative


Leukocytes
negative


pH
6.0


Specific gravity
1.005


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?

choices.text: Standing for long periods of time
Increased production of low molecular weight proteins
Loss of negative charge on the glomerular basement membrane
Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with increased protein excretion at the end of the day (i.e., 3+ on urine dipstick after an 8-hour shift at work) and normal protein excretion at the start of the day (after being in a recumbent position during the night), which, along with his normal renal function, is highly suggestive of orthostatic proteinuria (postural proteinuria), a type of benign proteinuria. Orthostatic proteinuria is characterized by increased protein excretion only in the upright position. This condition typically occurs in overweight adolescents and resolves spontaneously without treatment.

This patient's sensorineural hearing loss most likely occurred as a result of continuous exposure to loud noise at work without the use of appropriate hearing protection and is unlikely to be related to his increased urine protein excretion.

B) INCORRECT:

Subepithelial immune complex depositions are found in patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). While PSGN can manifest with proteinuria, typically 1–3 weeks following an upper respiratory infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci, it usually manifests with findings of nephritic syndrome such as hypertension, hematuria, and edema.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased production of low molecular weight proteins can lead to overflow proteinuria. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including multiple myeloma, hemolysis, and rhabdomyolysis. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of these conditions (e.g., jaundice and episodes of red/dark urine in the case of hemolysis). Moreover, the conditions would not explain why this patient presents with different rates of protein excretion depending on the time of the day (he only has mild proteinuria in the morning).

D) INCORRECT:

Loss of negative charge on glomerular basement membrane suggests minimal change disease (MCD). While MCD can manifest with proteinuria, often precipitated by upper respiratory infections, features of nephrotic syndrome such as edema and hypoalbuminemia would be expected. Moreover, MCD would not explain why this patient has different rates of protein excretion depending on the time of the day (he only has mild proteinuria in the morning).

E) INCORRECT:

Nodules within glomeruli (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane can be seen in diabetic nephropathy. Early in the course of the disease, this complication of diabetes mellitus typically manifests with asymptomatic proteinuria (microalbuminuria). However, this patient has no history of diabetes mellitus and no glucosuria on urinalysis.

F) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane suggests Alport syndrome. Alport syndrome usually affects males and causes sensorineural hearing loss and episodes of proteinuria, which are often precipitated by upper respiratory infections. However, almost all patients with Alport syndrome present with gross hematuria and a progressive decrease in kidney function (elevated BUN and serum creatinine). Furthermore, symptom onset is typically in infancy and affected individuals often have a personal or family history of ocular findings (e.g., lenticonus). This patient's mild hearing loss could be a result of repetitive loud noises at the shooting range without using appropriate hearing protection.
questions.hint: This overweight (BMI 28) but otherwise healthy adolescent presents with an incidental finding of proteinuria with normal renal function. The low concentration of protein (1+ on urine dipstick) in the patient's morning urine sample during the second examination can be interpreted as a normal finding, which is an important feature of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of several episodes of blood in his urine and decreased urine output for 5 days. His blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral lower extremity edema. Urinalysis shows 3+ protein and red blood cell casts. Mass spectrometry analysis of the urinary protein detects albumin, transferrin, and IgG. Which of the following best describes this type of proteinuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tubular proteinuria results from damage to the kidney tubules and failure to reabsorb small-sized proteins, such as beta-2 microglobulin. These micromolecules are freely filtered across the glomeruli and reabsorbed in the proximal tubule under normal circumstances. Tubulointerstitial diseases that disrupt the reabsorptive mechanisms of the kidney can cause tubular proteinuria. The lack of small-sized proteins in the mass spectrometry analysis of this patient's urine makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Overflow proteinuria is detected in diseases with increased production of proteins that exceed the reabsorption capacity of the tubules. Small-sized proteins, such as Bence-Jones proteins (due to multiple myeloma), hemoglobin (due to hemolysis), and myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis), are typically encountered in overflow proteinuria. The lack of small-sized proteins in the mass spectrometry analysis of this patient's urine, and the presence of albumin, transferrin, and IgG, makes the diagnosis of overflow proteinuria unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Selective glomerular proteinuria results from loss of the negative charge of the glomerular basement membrane and can be found in diseases that course with mild damage to the glomerular architecture (e.g., minimal change disease). Selective proteinuria is defined by the presence of small- to medium-sized proteins (predominantly albumin) in the urine, but other macromolecules, such as transferrin and IgG, are usually absent.

D) INCORRECT:

Postrenal proteinuria develops as a result of increased deposition of proteins in the urine from any part of the urinary tract that is distal to the renal pelvis. Causes of postrenal proteinuria include genitourinary infection, inflammation, trauma, nephrolithiasis, and tumors. Although small amounts of immunoglobulins, such as this patient's IgG, can be found in postrenal proteinuria, albumin and transferrin would not be expected.

E) CORRECT:

Nonselective proteinuria (e.g., with a mix of albumin, transferrin, and IgG) results from increased permeability to macromolecules and frequently occurs in diseases that disrupt the glomerular basement membrane (e.g., RPGN). The glomerular damage can be caused by a variety of conditions such as autoimmune, hereditary, and infectious diseases. Unlike selective proteinuria that reflects mild distortion to the glomerular architecture, nonselective proteinuria reflects severe and extensive damage to the glomeruli.
questions.hint: The patient's hematuria, proteinuria, oliguria, hypertension, and peripheral edema are consistent with nephritic syndrome. The albumin, transferrin, and IgG detected in his urine are normally all found in the serum, indicating a breakdown of the barrier between systemic circulation and the nephron.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl returns for follow-up one month after undergoing evaluation for dysuria and urinary frequency. At the initial evaluation, a urinalysis revealed 3+ protein but was otherwise within normal limits.
At today’s follow-up, the patient is asymptomatic without dysuria, frequency, or urgency. Her blood pressure is 96/62 mm Hg, and her growth parameters are normal. She has no heart murmur, rash, or edema. A repeat urinalysis shows a pH of 6.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), a specific gravity of 1.015 (1.001–1.035), and 3+ protein, with no blood, leukocytes, nitrites, ketones, or glucose.
A complete blood count and electrolyte analysis are normal. Further testing reveals a serum creatinine concentration of 0.5 mg/dL (reference range, 0.3–0.7) and a serum albumin level of 3.9 g/dL (3.5–5.5). She has not submitted a first morning urine sample.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s proteinuria?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This 10-year-old girl is asymptomatic and is likely to have orthostatic proteinuria.

Proteinuria, a common laboratory finding, is usually benign rather than a marker of established kidney disease in asymptomatic children. The most common cause of proteinuria in asymptomatic school-age children is orthostatic proteinuria. Once proteinuria is identified, a first morning urine sample should be obtained; the absence of proteinuria on that sample would be consistent with a diagnosis of orthostatic proteinuria. Proteinuria may also be seen transiently with fever and after vigorous exercise.

In a symptomatic child, further evaluation is indicated. Edema, when present, is worrisome and may indicate nephrotic syndrome. Rash, joint pain or swelling, weight loss, or fever may indicate systemic disease. Hematuria, hypertension, and edema are seen in children with glomerulonephritis.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of asymptomatic proteinuria in a school-age child is orthostatic proteinuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Reflux nephropathy is unlikely in this case given the lack of a urinary tract infection with fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Minimal-change disease is the most common histology in children with nephrotic syndrome, but this child has none of the features of nephrotic syndrome (which include the triad of edema, low serum albumin levels, and nephrotic-range proteinuria).

D) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis may occur in a child with nephrotic syndrome or may be secondary to other conditions, such as HIV infection, obesity, or reflux nephropathy; it might also be associated with reduced renal function.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with thin basement membrane disease have microscopic hematuria and may have a family history of hematuria; however, proteinuria is uncommon.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl presents for follow-up one month after being seen in the emergency department (ED) for a febrile illness that has since resolved. During that ED visit, a urinalysis showed 3+ protein.
Her current blood pressure is 88/56 mm Hg, and her physical examination is normal. Urinalysis again shows 3+ protein and trace amounts of blood but no leukocytes, nitrites, ketones, or glucose. The specific gravity is 1.015 (reference range, 1.001–1.035), and the pH is 6.0 (5.0–9.0).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for evaluating this child’s proteinuria?

choices.text: Measure the random urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio
Measure the urine protein-to-creatinine ratio on a first morning void

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is used to identify hypercalciuria, which can cause a range of urinary findings, including hematuria and kidney stones, but does not cause proteinuria.

B) INCORRECT:

A urine culture would be appropriate if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected, but a UTI would not cause proteinuria alone.

C) CORRECT:

A urine dipstick is not a reliable method to assess the degree of proteinuria. Highly alkaline urine can cause a false-positive result, and very concentrated specimens can overestimate the degree of proteinuria. Instead, the preferred method is to measure a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio obtained on a first morning void.

Proteinuria in asymptomatic children has many potential causes, but the most common is a benign finding: orthostatic proteinuria. Children with orthostatic proteinuria typically have normal urinary protein excretion during the night but mildly increased urinary protein excretion during the daytime when they are active. In adolescents and young adults, this distinction can be determined with a 24-hour urine collection, but in young children, an easier strategy is to measure the urine protein-to-creatinine ratio on a first morning sample that represents urine from the preceding night. A normal ratio is 0–0.2 mg/mg.

If a child had proteinuria identified on a previous sample but not on the first morning sample, orthostatic proteinuria would be the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in evaluating a child who has had proteinuria noted on urinalysis on two occasions is to measure the urine protein-to-creatinine ratio on a first morning void.

D) INCORRECT:

Further evaluation, including a renal ultrasound, would be indicated if the first morning sample confirmed proteinuria with a protein-to-creatinine ratio >0.2 mg/mg.

E) INCORRECT:

In adolescents and young adults, this distinction can be determined with a 24-hour urine collection, but in young children, an easier strategy is to measure the urine protein-to-creatinine ratio on a first morning sample that represents urine from the preceding night.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 12-year-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He reports feeling well and has no history of serious illness. He has received all recommended screenings and immunizations for his age. His 7-year-old brother was treated for nephrotic syndrome 1 year ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Physical examination is normal. Urine dipstick shows 1+ protein. A subsequent early morning urinalysis shows the following:


Blood, urine
Negative


Glucose, urine
Negative


Protein, urine
Trace


Leukocyte esterase, urine
Negative


Nitrite, urine
Negative


RBC, urine
None


WBC, urine
0–1/hpf


Protein/creatinine ratio
0.2 (≤ 0.2)


Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measure serum creatinine and urea nitrogen.
Repeat urine dipstick in one year.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

24-hour urine protein collection could be helpful in gathering more information about this patient's proteinuria. Current guidelines, however, recommend a single-void urine protein/creatinine ratio in children because it is easier to acquire and correlates with the 24-hour urine protein study (creatinine is secreted at a relatively constant rate of 1 g/24 hours). 24-hour urine protein collection is indicated if patients present with proteinuria that is > 4 mg/m2/h.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipid profiles are used in the differential diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome because several etiologies manifest with hyperlipidemia. Although this patient has laboratory evidence of proteinuria, it is not close to nephrotic range proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day, which is equivalent to ∼ 3+ or 4+ on a dipstick reading, or a protein:creatinine ratio ≥ 3:1 on spot urine) and there are no other signs of nephrotic syndrome (e.g., edema). In addition, although a lipid profile is indicated in patients aged between 9 and 11 years, this patient has already received all age-appropriate screenings. Therefore, a lipid profile is unlikely to provide useful information at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine and BUN values provide insight into renal function and can be used to help identify acute kidney injury (AKI) or monitor renal activity if an AKI has already been diagnosed. However, this patient shows no signs of AKI (e.g, oliguria, hematuria); measuring serum creatinine and BUN would be unnecessary at this time.

D) CORRECT:

This afebrile child initially presented with ≥ 1+ proteinuria, after which repeat testing of the first-morning urine and urinalysis with microscopic examination were indicated. The follow-up test showed normal urinalysis findings and a normal urinary protein/creatinine ratio (UPCR) ≤ 0.2, making transient proteinuria the most likely diagnosis. This type of benign proteinuria has an excellent prognosis; usually, no treatment is necessary. Therefore, a repeat urine dipstick of first-morning urine in one year is the most appropriate next step in management.

Key learning point: Transient proteinuria in children with normal follow-up urinalysis and protein/creatinine ratio requires no immediate intervention; annual repeat urine dipstick is sufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is the preferred method of assessing for anatomical abnormalities of the kidneys and urinary tract. It can quickly identify hydronephrosis, megaureter, polycystic kidneys, and other structural pathologies. This imaging study is indicated in the work-up of proteinuria with chronic kidney disease. The patient described here has no history of kidney disease, making ultrasound inappropriate at this time.
